title: Ticket #1613: [RFE] New ClassAd function - unparse()
description:
The ClassAd language contains two types that are intimately related: strings and expressions. The language also contains tools to dissect and manipulate strings. It does not contain tools to manipulate expressions. Proposed is the first tool for expression manipulation: quote(). Unlike string(), which evaluates the expression before converting it to a string, quote() directly converts the expression into a string. The string tools become available, and the existence of eval() becomes even more interesting.

One concrete use case for quote() is parsing Requirements expressions. For example, detecting if DiskUsage is referenced within job ads: 

   condor_q -constraint 'regexp(".*DiskUsage.*", quote(Requirements))'
remarks:
2010-Sep-30 06:16:24 by matt:
http://www.cs.wisc.edu/condor/classad/refman/node4.html#SECTION00043900000000000000

string(any x) returns string. 

  If x is a String, the result is x. Otherwise, the result is the canonical unparsing of x (see Section 3.3.3).

http://www.cs.wisc.edu/condor/classad/refman/node3.html#sec:unparsing

The canonical unparsing of an expression is completely parenthesized and has no comments and no whitespace outside of string literals or attribute names. For example, the strings ``-x + 3 * (y + 1)'' and ``((-x)+(3*(y+1)))'' both parse to the same internal form. The second string is the canonical unparsing.

2010-Sep-30 10:17:09 by danb:
Hmm. I haven't thought about it deeply, but the spec for string() seems quite unexpected to me. I would expect string() to coerce its evaluated argument to a string, just like int() coerces its evaluated argument to an integer.

I think we need two separate functions: one for coercing and one for unparsing. I'd recommend calling the unparser unparse() rather than quote().

Note that the spec for string() doesn't quite match what you are hoping for. "The canonical unparsing of an attribute name is simply the name itself." It seems that you were hoping for the attribute name to be expanded. Perhaps we need both "deep" and "shallow" variants of the unparser.

2010-Sep-30 11:11:53 by jfrey:
I suspect the spec assumes when an expression is a valid function argument, it's evaluated before use. The definition of 'const' arguments to functions probably needs refinement as well, but that's for another ticket.

I could see several behaviors desired for this quote()/unparse() function with regard to expanding attribute references:

  • No expansion. This could be useful if you want the unparsed expression in canonical form as a string.
  • Single expansion. If the expression consists of a single attribute reference (including scoping), expand that reference to its value, if possible, before unparsing. This would be Matt's example with condor_q -constraint.
  • Full expansion. Expand all attribute references in the expression, including references in the resulting values.

There could be an optional second parameter to the function which controls which form of expansion is used.

FWIW, I'd call it Unparse(). Quote() has a usual meaning in programming languages and what is described in this ticket is not it. :)

What is unparse() good for in its current form? It doesn't dereference any attributes in the argument. Instead of calling unparse(), you can write the expression as a string literal. You can't use it to print the Requirements or Start expression of a machine ad in condor_status: 
% condor_status -format '%s\n' 'unparse(start)'
start
start
%

Similarly, Matt's motivating example with condor_q at the top of this ticket won't work.

2011-Aug-11 15:00:53 by jfrey:
I propose making a small change to unparse() (patch attached). That will make the function act as follows:

  • Return Error if wrong number of arguments.
  • Return Error if argument isn't an attribute name.
  • Return an empty string if the attribute can't be found.
  • Else, return the unevaluated, unparsed value of the attribute as a string.

The unparse() function should be either entirely in or entirely out of 7.7.1. Right now, we have a broken version in 7.7.1 wit the fix on master.
